_metadata.description: Exhaustive cognitive bias taxonomy based on 4-domain functional classification

Availability_Heuristic.name: Availability Heuristic
Availability_Heuristic.definition: The tendency to overestimate the likelihood of events based on the ease with which examples come to mind. If an instance is readily retrieved—due to recency, vividness, or emotional impact—it is judged as frequent and probable.
Availability_Heuristic.low_entropy_insight: Notice: narrative universalizes a specific, recent, or emotional event. Consider broader context and statistical data.
examples: After seeing a plane crash on TV, I'm afraid to fly
I remember that one time it rained, so it must rain often
Availability_Heuristic.research_notes: Causes skew in risk assessment (e.g., fearing plane crashes more than car accidents). Triggered by vivid media, recent trauma, high emotional valence.
Availability_Heuristic.core_pattern: Relying on immediate examples that come to mind (often emotionally charged or recent) rather than comprehensive data

Attentional_Bias.name: Attentional Bias
Attentional_Bias.definition: The tendency for an individual's perception to be affected by their recurring thoughts at the time. We pay attention to what we are already thinking about, creating a feedback loop of salience.
Attentional_Bias.low_entropy_insight: Notice: attention is focused on specific themes. Consider whether this focus is helpful or creating a feedback loop.
examples: When I'm anxious, I notice every potential threat
After buying a car, I see that model everywhere
Attentional_Bias.research_notes: Critical in modeling addiction or anxiety, where cues related to the condition become hyper-salient.

Illusory_Truth_Effect.name: Illusory Truth Effect
Illusory_Truth_Effect.definition: The tendency to believe false information to be correct after repeated exposure. Repetition increases processing fluency, which the brain misinterprets as a signal of truthfulness.
Illusory_Truth_Effect.low_entropy_insight: Notice: belief may be based on repetition rather than evidence. Consider verifying the source and facts.
examples: After hearing a claim multiple times, I believe it's true
Repeated exposure to misinformation makes it seem credible
Illusory_Truth_Effect.research_notes: A foundational mechanism for the spread of misinformation and propaganda.

Mere_Exposure_Effect.name: Mere Exposure Effect
Mere_Exposure_Effect.definition: The psychological phenomenon by which people tend to develop a preference for things merely because they are familiar with them. In evolutionary terms, 'familiar' implies 'safe'.
Mere_Exposure_Effect.low_entropy_insight: Notice: preference may be based on familiarity rather than quality. Consider evaluating options objectively.
examples: I prefer brands I've seen advertised
Familiar faces seem more trustworthy
Mere_Exposure_Effect.research_notes: Application: Brand recognition and advertising optimization.

Confirmation_Bias.name: Confirmation Bias
Confirmation_Bias.definition: The tendency to search for, interpret, favor, and recall information in a way that confirms one's preexisting beliefs or hypotheses.
Confirmation_Bias.low_entropy_insight: Notice: narrative focuses on data that supports the core story. Consider alternative interpretations and contradictory evidence.
examples: I only notice evidence that supports my view
I interpret ambiguous information in favor of my beliefs
Confirmation_Bias.research_notes: Sub-types: Biased Search, Biased Interpretation, Biased Recall. Unlike Desirability Bias (believing what we want to be true), Confirmation Bias supports what we already believe, even if it is negative.
Confirmation_Bias.core_pattern: Tendency to search for, interpret, and recall information that confirms preexisting beliefs

Fundamental_Attribution_Error.name: Fundamental Attribution Error
Fundamental_Attribution_Error.definition: The tendency for people to under-emphasize situational explanations for an individual's observed behavior while over-emphasizing dispositional and personality-based explanations.
Fundamental_Attribution_Error.low_entropy_insight: Notice: narrative attributes outcome to personality rather than context. Consider situational factors and external circumstances.
examples: He's late because he's lazy
She failed because she's not smart
They're rude because they're a bad person
Fundamental_Attribution_Error.research_notes: Correspondence Bias assumes behavior matches personality; FAE is the general error.
Fundamental_Attribution_Error.core_pattern: Attributes other's behavior to character (internal) while attributing own behavior to situation (external)

Self_Serving_Bias.name: Self-Serving Bias
Self_Serving_Bias.definition: The tendency to perceive oneself in an overly favorable manner. Specifically, attributing success to internal factors (skill) and failure to external factors (luck/situation).
observable_markers: It was all because of me
I failed because of bad luck
Self_Serving_Bias.low_entropy_insight: Notice: narrative emphasizes personal agency in positive outcomes. Consider collaborative contributions and external factors in both success and failure.
examples: I got the promotion because I'm talented
I lost because the conditions were unfair
Self_Serving_Bias.research_notes: Antonym: Depressive Realism. Mechanism: Ego Defense / Self-Esteem Maintenance.
Self_Serving_Bias.core_pattern: Tendency to claim more credit for success than is due, or to see oneself as central to events

Loss_Aversion.name: Loss Aversion
Loss_Aversion.definition: The tendency to prefer avoiding losses to acquiring equivalent gains. The pain of losing $100 is psychologically about twice as powerful as the pleasure of gaining $100.
Loss_Aversion.low_entropy_insight: Notice: narrative emphasizes potential losses more than equivalent gains. Consider both sides of the equation and the actual probabilities.
examples: I won't sell my stock because I might lose money
I'd rather not risk losing $100 than gain $100
Loss_Aversion.research_notes: Core principle of Prospect Theory. Asymmetric valuation of gains and losses.
Loss_Aversion.core_pattern: Tendency to prefer avoiding losses rather than acquiring equivalent gains (pain of losing is psychologically twice as powerful as pleasure of gaining)

Sunk_Cost_Fallacy.name: Sunk Cost Fallacy
Sunk_Cost_Fallacy.definition: The phenomenon where a person is reluctant to abandon a strategy or course of action because they have invested heavily in it, even when it is clear that abandonment would be more beneficial.
observable_markers: I've put too much into this
Sunk_Cost_Fallacy.low_entropy_insight: Notice: narrative emphasizes past investment over future outcomes. Consider whether continuing is truly beneficial, regardless of past costs.
examples: I'll keep watching this bad movie because I paid for it
I can't leave this job, I've been here 10 years
Sunk_Cost_Fallacy.research_notes: Concorde Effect is the political instance; Escalation involves active investment increase.

Optimism_Bias.name: Optimism Bias
Optimism_Bias.definition: A cognitive bias that causes someone to believe that they themselves are less likely to experience a negative event.
Optimism_Bias.low_entropy_insight: Notice: narrative expresses unrealistic optimism about personal risk. Consider statistical probabilities and prepare for potential negative outcomes.
examples: I won't get cancer, that happens to other people
I won't be in a car accident
Optimism_Bias.research_notes: Mechanism: Self-Protection / Anxiety Reduction. Can flip to Pessimism Bias in depression.

Pessimism_Bias.name: Pessimism Bias
Pessimism_Bias.definition: The tendency for some people, especially those suffering from depression, to overestimate the likelihood of negative things happening to them.
observable_markers: Things always go wrong for me
Pessimism_Bias.low_entropy_insight: Notice: narrative expresses unrealistic pessimism about outcomes. Consider that negative events may be less likely than perceived, and positive outcomes are possible.
examples: I'll probably fail the exam
Something bad will happen if I try
Pessimism_Bias.research_notes: Mechanism: Depressive Realism (in some definitions). Common in depression and anxiety.

Reactive_Devaluation.name: Reactive Devaluation
Reactive_Devaluation.definition: A cognitive bias that occurs when a proposal is devalued if it appears to originate from an antagonist.
observable_markers: I don't like it because they suggested it
Reactive_Devaluation.low_entropy_insight: Notice: proposal is evaluated based on source rather than merit. Consider the idea independently of who suggested it.
examples: I reject their proposal because I don't like them
Their idea must be bad because they suggested it
Reactive_Devaluation.core_pattern: Automatic dismissal or devaluation of a proposal simply because it originated from an adversary

Zero_Sum_Bias.name: Zero Sum Bias
Zero_Sum_Bias.definition: A cognitive bias towards thinking that a situation is a zero-sum game, where one person's gain would be another's loss.
Zero_Sum_Bias.low_entropy_insight: Notice: narrative frames outcomes as binary (Win/Lose) rather than collaborative. Consider mutual gains and non-zero-sum solutions.
examples: If they win, I lose
There's only so much to go around
Their success means my failure
Zero_Sum_Bias.core_pattern: Assumption that everything that benefits the other party must harm us (and vice versa); belief that interests are mutually exclusive

Role_Victim.name: Role: Victim
Role_Victim.definition: Narrative places Self as acted upon rather than acting (passive victim role).
Role_Victim.low_entropy_insight: Notice: narrative positions self as passive recipient. Consider active choices and agency in the situation.
examples: I had no choice but to do that
They made me do it
I'm powerless in this situation
Role_Victim.research_notes: Narrative role pattern indicating passive positioning.
Role_Victim.core_pattern: Narrative places Self as acted upon rather than acting (passive victim role)

Role_Dragon.name: Role: Dragon
Role_Dragon.definition: Narrative assigns total responsibility for problems to the Other; assumes injurious intent (villain role).
Role_Dragon.low_entropy_insight: Notice: narrative assigns total responsibility and assumes injurious intent. Consider multiple perspectives and shared responsibility.
examples: They're trying to sabotage me
They did this on purpose to hurt me
They're the enemy
Role_Dragon.research_notes: Narrative role pattern indicating villain attribution.
Role_Dragon.core_pattern: Narrative assigns total responsibility for problems to the Other; assumes injurious intent (villain role)

Role_Prince.name: Role: Prince
Role_Prince.definition: Narrative looks for external salvation or simplistic solutions (rescuer role).
Role_Prince.low_entropy_insight: Notice: narrative seeks external solutions. Consider internal agency and incremental change.
examples: If only the government would fix this
All we need is a hero
Someone will come and save us
Role_Prince.research_notes: Narrative role pattern indicating external solution seeking.
Role_Prince.core_pattern: Narrative looks for external salvation or simplistic solutions (rescuer role)
